Foundational Knowledge.Description: Learn essential Unreal Engine 5 concepts and its learning ecosystem.
Foundational Knowledge.Unreal Engine 5: A real-time 3D engine for creating games, visualizations, and immersive experiences.
Foundational Knowledge.Preparation: Familiarize yourself with fundamental tools and concepts before developing.

Unreal Editor Interface.Description: Overview of the key elements of the Unreal Editor interface.

Elements.Name: Main Toolbar
Elements.Description: Shortcuts for common tools, editors, and Play mode.

Elements.Name: Level Viewport
Elements.Description: Displays contents of your Level, such as Cameras and Actors.

Elements.Name: Content Drawer
Elements.Description: Opens Content Drawer to access all project Assets.

Elements.Name: Bottom Toolbar
Elements.Description: Shortcuts to Command Console, Output Log, and Derived Data.

Elements.Name: Outliner
Elements.Description: Hierarchical tree view of all content in your Level.

Elements.Name: Details Panel
Elements.Description: Displays properties for selected Actor in the Level.

Menu Bar.Description: Located at the top of the editor window, contains File, Window, and Help menus.

Sections.Name: Mode Selection
Sections.Description: Shortcuts for editing modes: Select, Landscape, Foliage, Mesh Painting, Fracture, Brush.

Shortcuts.Name: Create
Shortcuts.Description: Quickly add common Assets to your Level.

Shortcuts.Name: Cinematics
Shortcuts.Description: Create Level Sequence or Master Sequence.

Sections.Name: Play Mode Controls
Sections.Description: Buttons to Play, Skip, Stop, and Eject game in the Editor.

Sections.Name: Platforms Menu
Sections.Description: Configure and deploy project to various platforms.

Sections.Name: Settings
Sections.Description: Editor, Level Editor Viewport, and game settings.

Views.Name: Orthographic
Views.Description: 2D view from one of the main axes (X, Y, Z).

Content Drawer and Content Browser.Description: File explorer for project Assets, Blueprints, and files.

Content Drawer.Description: Opens minimized Content Browser. Can be docked.

Sections.Name: Command Console
Sections.Description: Command line interface for specific editor behaviors.

Outliner.Description: Hierarchical view of all Level content.

Details Panel.Description: Shows settings and properties of selected Actor.

Unreal Engine Terminology.Description: Commonly used terms when working with Unreal Engine.

Terms.Name: Project
Terms.Description: Holds all game contents; contains folders like Blueprints and Materials. Each project has a .uproject file.

Terms.Name: Blueprint
Terms.Description: Node-based visual scripting system for gameplay elements.

Terms.Name: Object
Terms.Description: Basic class in Unreal Engine; base class is UObject.

Terms.Name: Class
Terms.Description: Defines behaviors and properties of an Actor or Object; hierarchical.

Terms.Name: Actor
Terms.Description: Object placed in a level, supporting 3D transformations; base class is AActor.

Terms.Name: Casting
Terms.Description: Action to treat an Actor as a different class; enables access to class-specific functionality.

Terms.Name: Component
Terms.Description: Adds functionality to an Actor, e.g., lighting, movement.

Terms.Name: Pawn
Terms.Description: Subclass of Actor; serves as in-game avatar, controllable by player or AI.

Terms.Name: Character
Terms.Description: Subclass of Pawn; intended as player character with additional movement code.

Terms.Name: Player Controller
Terms.Description: Translates player input to game interactions; key for multiplayer games.

Terms.Name: AI Controller
Terms.Description: Possesses a Pawn for NPCs in a game.

Terms.Name: Player State
Terms.Description: State of a game participant, containing info like name, health, and score.

Terms.Name: Game Mode
Terms.Description: Sets game rules, player joining, and win conditions.

Terms.Name: Game State
Terms.Description: Holds information replicated to every client, e.g., game score.

Terms.Name: Brush
Terms.Description: Actor describing 3D shape; used for level geometry.

Terms.Name: Volume
Terms.Description: Bounded 3D spaces with specific effects, e.g., blocking, damage.

Terms.Name: World
Terms.Description: Container for all Levels, managing level streaming and dynamic Actor spawning.

Tools and Editors.Description: Overview of different types of editors in Unreal Engine 5.

Definitions.Tool: Used to perform specific tasks, e.g., placing Actors.
Definitions.Editor: Collection of tools for complex tasks, e.g., Level Editor.
Definitions.System: Large collection of features working together, e.g., Blueprint system.

Tools and Editors.Notes: Some tools and editors are built-in, others are optional plugins.

Editors.Name: Level Editor
Editors.Description: Primary editor for constructing gameplay levels.

Editors.Name: Static Mesh Editor
Editors.Description: Preview and set properties of Static Meshes.

Editors.Name: Material Editor
Editors.Example: Apply a dirt Material to floors.

Editors.Name: Blueprint Editor
Editors.Description: Modify Blueprints to create gameplay elements without C++.

Editors.Name: Physics Asset Editor
Editors.Description: Create Physics Assets for Skeletal Meshes.

Editors.Name: Behavior Tree Editor
Editors.Description: Script AI behaviors using a node-based system.

Editors.Name: Niagara Editor
Editors.Description: Create particle effects with modular emitters.

Editors.Name: UMG UI Editor
Editors.Description: Create UI elements like HUDs and menus.

Editors.Name: Font Editor
Editors.Description: Add, organize, and preview Font Assets.

Editors.Name: Sequencer Editor
Editors.Description: Create in-game cinematics with a multi-track editor.

Editors.Name: Animation Editor
Editors.Description: Edit Skeleton Assets, Skeletal Meshes, and Animation Blueprints.

Editors.Name: Control Rig Editor
Editors.Description: Rig and animate characters directly in-engine.

Editors.Name: Sound Cue Editor
Editors.Description: Define audio playback behavior with Sound Cues.

Editors.Name: Media Editor
Editors.Description: Define media files or URLs for playback.

Editors.Name: nDisplay 3D Config Editor
Editors.Description: Render scenes on multiple synchronized display devices.

Editors.Name: DMX Library Editor
Editors.Description: Customize devices and commands for live-events.

Onboarding Guide for Games Licensees.Description: Steps to get started with Unreal Engine.

Windows.Processor: Quad-core Intel or AMD, 2.5 GHz or faster

Linux.Processor: Quad-core Intel or AMD, 2.5 GHz or faster

Prerequisite Installer.Description: Installs necessary components for running the editor and engine.

Lumen.Hardware Ray Tracing: DirectX 12, RTX-2000, RX-6000, or Intel Arc

Temporal Super Resolution.Requirements: Shader Model 5, SM6 for better performance

Methods: Download from Epic's Perforce proxy server
GitHub Access Steps: Link GitHub to Epic Games account

Steps: Set solution configuration to Development Editor
Open connection with provided server info

Onboarding Guide for Non-Games Licensees.Description: Steps to get started with Unreal Engine for non-games licensees.

Term Definitions.UDN: Unreal Developer Network for custom license support.
Term Definitions.Unreal Engine: Suite of tools for creating interactive experiences.
Term Definitions.Unreal Editor: Interface for developing with Unreal Engine.
Term Definitions.Epic Games Launcher: Platform for installing and managing Unreal Engine.
Term Definitions.Datasmith: Import tool for CAD, BIM, and 3D content.

Steps.Description: Set up UDN access for technical administrators and staff.
Install Unreal Engine via the Epic Games Launcher or other methods.
Launch Unreal Editor from the Launcher or installation directory.
Create a new project from a template.
Start learning with the Online Learning Platform and Documentation.
Get help from UDN or the public community.

Epic Account.Description: Create an Epic account for access to Unreal Engine features.

UDN Access.Description: Primary technical contact grants UDN access to staff.

Security.Description: Enable Two-Factor Authentication for account security.

Requirements.Windows: Windows 10 64-bit, Quad-core Intel/AMD, 8 GB RAM, DirectX 11/12 GPU
Requirements.MacOS: MacOS 13 Ventura, Apple Silicon M3, 32 GB RAM, Metal 1.2 GPU
Requirements.Linux: Ubuntu 22.04, Quad-core Intel/AMD, 32 GB RAM, GeForce 2080

Acquiring Unreal Engine.Source Code: Download from GitHub or Perforce for custom needs.

Methods: Log into Epic Games Launcher and click Launch
Navigate to installation directory and launch executable

Creating Projects.Description: Use Project Browser to create new projects or open existing ones.

Sample Projects.Description: Access example projects from the Learn tab in the Launcher.

Documentation.Description: Access quick-start guides, reference manuals, and programming guides.

Learning Videos.Description: Online Learning Platform offers on-demand tutorials.

UDN.Description: Premium support for custom licensees through UDN.

Community.Description: Engage with the public community on Unreal Engine Forums.

Contact.Description: Reach out to Business Development Manager or email developer-access@unrealengine.com.

Directory Structure.Description: Overview of the directories that make up the engine and game projects.

Root Directory.Name: Engine
Root Directory.Description: Contains all source code, content, and tools for the engine.

Root Directory.Name: Templates
Root Directory.Description: Collection of project templates available when creating new projects.

Root Directory.Name: GenerateProjectFiles.bat
Root Directory.Description: Creates Unreal Engine solution and project files for Visual Studio.

Root Directory.Name: Default.uprojectdirs
Root Directory.Description: Helper file that allows the engine to discover projects in subdirectories.

Common Directories.Name: Binaries
Common Directories.Description: Contains executable files created during compiling.

Common Directories.Name: Build
Common Directories.Description: Files needed for building the engine or game, including platform-specific builds.

Common Directories.Name: Content
Common Directories.Description: Holds content for the engine or game, including asset packages and maps.

Common Directories.Name: DerivedDataCache
Common Directories.Description: Contains derived data files generated on-load for referenced content.

Common Directories.Name: Intermediate
Common Directories.Description: Temporary files generated during building the engine or game.

Common Directories.Name: Plugins
Common Directories.Description: Contains plugins used in the engine.

Common Directories.Name: Saved
Common Directories.Description: Contains autosaves, configuration (.ini) files, and log files.

Common Directories.Name: Source
Common Directories.Description: All source files for engine or game.

Engine.Name: Developer
Engine.Description: Files used by both the editor and engine.

Engine.Name: Editor
Engine.Description: Files used by just the editor.

Engine.Name: Programs
Engine.Description: External tools used by the engine or editor.

Engine.Name: Runtime
Engine.Description: Files used by just the engine.

Game.Name: Classes
Game.Description: Contains all gameplay class header (.h) files.

Game.Name: Private
Game.Description: Contains all source (.cpp) files including gameplay class implementation files.

Modules and Plugins.Description: Unreal Engine functionality is organized into modules and plugins.

Modules.Description: Contain only code, organized with a *.Build.cs file.

Plugins.Description: Contain source files, binaries, and a .uplugin file. Can also contain assets.

Engine-specific Directories.Name: Documentation
Engine-specific Directories.Description: Contains engine documentation, both source and published files.

Engine-specific Directories.Name: Programs
Engine-specific Directories.Description: Contains configuration files and log files for projects stored in the Unreal Engine root directory.

Engine-specific Directories.Name: Shaders
Engine-specific Directories.Description: Holds the shader source files (.usf) for the engine.
